Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Modeling Sustainable, Resilient, and Robust Infrastructure Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
In support of NSF/ENG's Emerging Frontiers in Research Innovation (EFRI) Resilient and Sustainable Infrastructures (RESIN) portfolio of projects, all eight RESIN project teams as well as other invitees from across the nation will convene at Champaign, Illinois on November 17-18, 2011 in order to (i) finalize overarching metrics for sustainability, resilience, and robustness (SRR) of critical infrastructure systems, and (ii) promote implementation of these synthesized metrics in infrastructure system modeling across various application contexts. Another principal objective is to strategize on means to overcome critical conceptual and computational barriers that are common across RESIN projects. Secondary objectives are to coordinate RESIN educational and outreach activities, and to discuss future opportunities and a path forward for the RESIN community. At the workshop, each RESIN team will make presentations summarizing their modeling efforts to date. New concepts and broader definitions will be provided by invited experts to provide additional breadth and depth to the discussion. Breakout sessions will be held on specific topics (i.e., metrics, modeling, and engineering implications of SRR, and education, outreach and future research opportunities). This workshop, via the advancement of new engineering standards and guidelines for achieving sustainability, resilience and robustness in infrastructure systems, is targeted to have a significant impact on infrastructure system modeling across multiple engineering disciplines. The workshop materials will be documented (e.g., via videotaping, voice recording) and will be available for downloading permanently at the conference website. The deliverables include (i) a workshop report to NSF including a summary of breakout sessions, (ii) a finalized summary paper of interdisciplinary definitions of SRR, and (iii) a technical report and/or compiled book chapters that summarize the quantitative applications of SRR concepts/definitions in various infrastructure contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In support of the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) Emerging Frontiers in Research Innovation (EFRI), Resilient and Sustainable Infrastructures (RESIN) program, an interdisciplinary research team at the University of Illinois convened all RESIN research teams, as well as representatives and invited speakers from NSF and other institutions, in order to discuss topics such as the following: (i) Common definitions of infrastructure sustainability, resiliency, and robustness (SRR); (ii) Implementations of SRR; (iii) Computational needs; and (iv) Outreach activities. The workshop was held at the I-Hotel and Conference Center in Champaign, Illinois, on November 17-18, 2011. The objectives were to

(i)     finalize overarching metrics for sustainability, resilience, and robustness (SRR) of critical infrastructures,

(ii)   promote implementations of these synthesized metrics in infrastructure system modeling across various application contexts, and

(iii) identify issues and exchange experiences that are related to the computational barriers in achieving sustainable, resilient and robust interrelated critical infrastructures of the nation.

Over fifty registered attendees participated in the workshop, including four invited speakers. At the workshop, each RESIN team and each invited speaker made a presentation summarizing the related research efforts. New concepts and broader definitions were provided and discussed by several experts on the individual measures (and in panels) with additional breadth and depth.  Breakout sessions were held on by topic (i.e., metrics, modeling, and engineering implications of S, R and R, respectively).  At the end of the workshop, the group moved toward the focused RESIN issues of education, outreach and future research possibilities

An overview of the workshop as well as key recommendations is provided in this report. The participants generally felt that the workshop helped us take another significant step towards creating a community of researchers, generating the research momentum, and coordinating the pool of talent, ideas, and innovation toward theoretical research and quantitative applications of SRR concepts/definitions to various infrastructure contexts. A permanent workshop website is available at http://ict.illinois.edu/conferences/RESINworkshop2011/ with all the relevant details regarding the workshop. All workshop activities have been documented (e.g., via video taping and photo taking) for downloading at this website.
